Unit 3: Static Site Generation (SSG)

  • How It Works:
    • HTML is pre-rendered at build time, producing static files.
  • Security:
    • Pre-rendered pages do not connect directly to APIs or databases, enhancing security.
  • Data Injection:
    • Use a CMS to populate data fields before rendering.
      • Example: Like setting concrete for a sidewalk â€” changes require rebuilding the whole structure.
    • Serverless functions allow asynchronous data pulling/pushing for updates.
  • API Limitations:
    • Without a CMS, data can only be fetched during deployment.
    • Recommended to use a CDN for better performance and reliability.

Unit 3: Client-Side Rendering (CSR)

  • How It Works:
    • The browser renders the page using the client's computer resources.
  • Dynamic Updates:
    • JavaScript updates the Document Object Model (DOM) after initial load.
    • Only necessary data is fetched on refresh, avoiding a complete rebuild of the site.

Unit 3: Server-Side Rendering (SSR)

  • How It Works:
    • Pages are generated on-demand by the server.
  • Advantages:
    • Ideal for applications requiring dynamic, time-sensitive data (e.g., banking).
  • Limitations:
    • High frequency of data transfers (pushing/pulling) between client and server.
